Memento mori is a Latin phrase meaning ‘remember you must die’ that dates back to the ancient practice of reflection on the topic of our mortality.

If properly understood, the phrase memento mori is not supposed to instil fear or apprehension, but rather an appreciation for the life we have been given, and to realize the urgency of our actions.

From a young age the topic of death has fascinated the artist Meyoko. In her Adulthood she informed herself on the topic as much as she could, searching for myths and legends surrounding the phenomenon, keen on feasting on a wide array of stories to fill the blank pages of her sketchbooks. It was then that she stumbled upon an Ancient Latin saying: Memento Mori. An object kept as a reminder of the inevitability of death, such as a skull. Due to many reasons, those words reached out to her, and inspired her to put her pen to paper, and create her series of Skulls.

Alaus Oculatus Simurgh no.1, acrilyc on paper

Acherontia Atropos Ballpoint pen on paper and digital manipulation

Anacridium Ballpoint pen on paper and digital manipulation

Using the medium of a ballpoint pen on Aquarelle paper, Meyoko drew the skulls with meticulous detail, employing modern technologies at the end of the creative process to make the symmetry look faultless. Her greatest sources for inspiration proved to be the tribal face paints of the Ethiopian Omo Valley tribe, as well as the Congolese Efe pygmy tribes, who draw on their bodies using various colorful minerals.

Throughout her research, it was revealed to her that these different tribes paint their faces for many reasons and purposes, though the belief that they could ward off evil and ill intent fascinated her the most. She also expressed an interest in the Egyptian beliefs surrounding the topic of Immortality, as well as their myths anent the sacred beetle, who symbolized the steps towards rebirth, notably the process of resurrection, transformation, and protection. But nothing motivated Murillo more than Paul Koudounaris’s book Heavenly Bodies, who brought the bejeweled Skulls of martyred Saints to light in a macabre display of opulence and religion.

Pomponia Imperatoria Ballpoint pen, watercolor on paper and digital manipulation

Pazuzu Ballpoint pen, watercolor on paper and digital manipulation

Anamnesis Ballpoint pen on paper and digital manipulation

Anacridium Black Ballpoint pen on paper and digital manipulation
